Received
July 21st 1921
Baghdad June 19
1921
Dearest Father . There have been 2 mails this week
bringing your letters of May 11 + 18 but oddly enough
nothing from Mother . However It's just an accident or
she may have been unusually busy. I return you the memo about
my income tax filled in to the best of my ability. As far as
I know the
India office British government department to oversee the administration of the provinces of India for the British Empire
was still paying us up to Ap 4
but possibly the last month of the financial year may have been
on the charge of the Middle Eastern
Dept
Department
of the Colonial
office. The letter of Lord Ashfield in
the Times
The Times. Amalgamated Press
is an
excellent + timely contribution to
the controversy The 1921 Miners’ Strike which occurred after the re-privatisation of the mines following the First World War.
. Ultimately
the arguments he uses must prevail because they are facts
from which you can't escape. The whole question is whether
people will recognise + bow to them in time, or will wait
till disaster forces the recognition of them. Isn't that it? I
gather from Reuters that the immediate struggle is coming
to an end. What you say about the
supine-ness supineness
of the public
is very curious, but at any rate there has been nothing which
looks like social upheaval or a class bitterness
We here are now launched on our perilous way. On Monday
my old friend the Mayor, Abdul Majid Shawi - we had tea with him
just before you left, you remember - came to my office + said that
since Faisal was coming it was up to the Notables of Baghdad
to make a proper reception for him + not to leave it all to the
young extremists - of whom the notables are very jealous. Faisal
was a famous Arab - the son of a King + must be treated
as such. I said I thought that view perfectly proper; he as the
Mayor of the town, should make the arrangements. There followed
him Naji Suwaidi , who is the leading man of the younger group.
+ I begged him to take advantage of Abdul Majid' s attitude +
let the older men assume the lead because they were the people
to conciliate. He promised to do so but I don't think the relations

to the Council , who stopped me + told me this excellent news.
I rode on much cheered + when I got home found a letter
from Sir Percy enclosing the long-expected communiqué
which he told me to get through to Ja'far or Naji
Suwaidi before the meeting which was to take place
at 8 next morning. By good luck Ja'far with his wife
+ sister were dining so I translated the communiqué
to them + gave it to Ja'far for the meeting. They
were all delighted with it + indeed it was
just what we wanted.
Next day Naji Suwaidi, + the Mutasarrif, Rashid
Beg, came to my office after the meeting to report.
It had been a great success, everyone had been
present + 60 people had been chosen to go down
to Basrah to welcome Faisal - would I kindly
make arrangements with the railway. There remained
the question of his lodging here which they proposed to
solve by putting him into some rooms in the Sarai
(the Government offices) which were now under repair
They included the old Turkish Council chamber + seemed
to be quite suitable, if they could be got ready in
time. Public Works declared at first that it could not
be done. Ja'far telephoned to me in despair on Sat.
morning; I telephoned to Public Works, made suggestions
for covering bare walls with hangings + finally the
thing was arranged
In the evening I went to the Naqib , whom I found
receiving the report of the Reception Committee. Directly
I got in he showed me a telegram which had just
come to him from King Husain couched in very suitable

work out quite happily. It's a matter which needs very
careful watching + any help one can discreetly give it.
The younger men have frequented my office this
week. We had to settle on a temporary flag - I
suppose the Constituent Assembly will have the final word there -
+ then there was the difficult question as to where Faisal
should be lodged. If only we had got the official communiqué
from home earlier everything would have been much easier.
We should have been able to give a more decided lead to
the people + a more decided warning to our own officers.
As it was our friends here of the Abdul Majid type were
always trying to find out what the British
Government
really
wanted + we couldn't in plain words tell them, while
our officers were advocating, tacitly or openly, that the
final decision as to the sovereign should be put off for
a term of years, or that we should begin with a
republic so as to let the country find itself - neither of
which propositions would the home Govt take on. The Govt
is right I think because the country won't find itself till
we give it a lead, postponement only means continual
discontent on the part of the Nationalists + resulting intrigue,
+ as for a republic we've not reached the stage of
political equilibrium at which we could contemplate
with equanimity the periodical upheaval of a
presidential election. It's true however that we're gently
pushing the country into a Nationalist path which
at this moment it doesn't view with much favour.
The point of view of the Naqib + his group must be
sympathetically considered. Their argument is that they
witnessed the young extremists make a mess of Syria
+ they don't want a repetition of those events here. They
disapproved of
the rebellion Iraqi Revolt of 1920 against the British suppressed by the British using heavy artillery and aerial bombardment.
last year + now they see the

very men who organized it all pardoned under
the amnesty Amnesty issued by the British government in which those imprisoned for their involvement in the 1920 Iraqi revolt were pardoned.
+ presumably coming back with Faisal to boast that in
the end they have won + to take the top places. That's
their openly expressed fear + it's a thing we must do
our utmost not to allow. I believe Faisal is statesman
enough to realize that he must capture + rely upon
the older more steady going people whilst at the same
time not chilling overmuch the enthusiasm of his more ardent
supporters.
Well, to continue my tale. Time was, as Miss Thomson used to
say, fierce. Here was Faisal arriving at Basrah on the 23rd +
we still without any communiqué from home. We had actually
never said officially that he was arriving. But his
partisans were growing naturally impatient + anxious to get.
busy. Sir Percy realized this + unofficially approved the
project presented through me - in my capacity as the
Nabi Here Bell refers back to a comment made by Haji Naji, described in a previous letter, where he referred to Bell as the ‘Prophet Jesus’ to the High Commissioners ‘God Almighty’.
'Isa, you understand - that they should summon the town
to a big meeting on Friday, 6 days before Faisal's arrival.
As soon as the invitations were out, in the name of Naji
Suwaidi, bishops + others dropped in to my office to sound
me as to whether they ought to go. "Oh yes" said I
"why not? the meeting has the approval of
H. E.
His Excellency
" On
Thursday afternoon the Naqib, like the old gentleman he
is, made a sound move. He informed the Council of
Ministers that Faisal was coming + that they must
make preparations to receive him properly + see that he
was suitably lodged. Thereupon they appointed a reception
committee of 5 Ministers, including Abdul Majid +
Ja'far Pasha . I had been out riding after tea + on
the way home I met Saiyid Husain 'Afnan , the secretary

terms + announcing that he was sending
his son Faisal to him. I wasn't as much
surprised as I might have been for we
had urgently telegraphed in the beginning
of the week to say that Husain must send some
message of this kind to the Naqib . The Naqib
then read me his reply drafted by Saiyid Husain ,
"What?" he said "what?" peering at it, + then
took a pen + cut out some of the honorifics which
Saiyid Husain had thought fit to prefix to the King's
name. However he left quite enough + we all
expressed our approval.
This morning, being Sunday, Mr Tod + I rode before
breakfast to Haji Naji whom we found sitting
with an old Saiyid of Karradah who is rather
a friend of mine. Haji Naji presently drew me aside +
told me he thought of going with the party to Basrah
only he was rather afraid of being lost in the ruck.
I said I would give him a letter of introduction
to Mr Cornwallis who is coming with Faisal so
that he might be treated with consideration. This
entirely satisfied him + we returned to the
summer house to eat the excellent apricots +
apples which he set before us. Finally I sent
for 'Abdul Majid Shawi + Fakhri Jamil + had
a long heart to heart talk with them - they are
both on the Naqib's Reception Committee. They seem
quite happy so I hope things are going well. They've just left.
By the way I must tell you that on Friday morning

river by launch, with Mr Tod + a party, to swim.
We take dinner with us + eat it on the
way back - he provides the drinks + I the
food.
Ever beloved family your very affectionate
daughter
Gertrude

Haji Naji also came to my office after the meeting +
as good luck would have it your clippers
arrived just at that moment. So we opened
+ admired them + Haji Naji observed conversationally
to the others there "Whenever her Father goes to
London he sends me a present." He was very
much delighted + the fact that the gift was
made before others was all to the good.
Fakhri Jamil begs me to say to you that he
sent you his photograph, but you haven't sent
him yours in return!
In the middle of all these absorbing events, I went
to a ball given by the Philbys at
the Club Possibly either the Railway or the Alwiyah Social Club but other social clubs existed in Baghdad at this time.
. I didn't
dance but I sat out in the garden, + talked to
lots of people. I was passably amused but I felt
too full of other things to be able to give much
attention to balls. It's a perfect mania here, balls.
I never go, but they dance at the Club 3 or 4
times a week. It's accursed, I think. Men who
are as hard worked as our officials can't sit
up till one or two in the morning + be in their
offices at 7 or 8. It's the wives that do it,
confound them. They take no sort of interest in
what's going on, know no Arabic + see no Arabs
They create an exclusive (though it's also a very
second rate) English society, quite cut off from the

life of the town.
I now begin to understand why
British
Govt Government
has come to grief in India India was under rule of the British Empire at this time.
where
our women do just the same thing. Mr Philby
told me that he was worn out. He is also
rather on edge because he is very anti-
Sharifian Term referring to things or people related to or supportive of the Sharif (a title used to describe those - usually royal - claiming descent from the prophet Muhammad), in this case Mr Philby is opposed to the idea of a system headed by a Sharif.
+ has taken
H. M. G. His Majesty's Government
' s policy ill.
I told him I wasn't going to let any politics
make a difference to our friendship + he
was delightful on that head. But it's no
good for a Govt servant to be in opposition
to official policy + he has done some harm
by openly advocating a republic. Sir Percy has
now stopped him but he can't be expected to
put his back into the job + the Sharifians all
look on him as an adversary. It's a great pity.
His wife is one of the worst of the ball goers
+ you'll scarcely believe it but Lady Cox goes to
every one + dances all night - with yon figure!
She is giving a ball this week to which I shall
have to go.
This afternoon I've got to call on the wife of
the Persian heir-apparent - they are on their
way through to Europe , glad to escape the
coming storm in Persia I should think. I know
her, she is a pretty little lady brought up
in Brussels . And after tea I'm going down

Sir Hugh Bell Bart. C B
Rounton Grange
Northallerton
England
GM Bell
